paragraphs.text: Mission: This is a statement that describes the problem you are setting out to solve, typically including who you are solving it for. This is often set at the company level, but can also be defined for a product or product line.
paragraphs.name: 673e

497c527412f2.title: Interestingly, I used a very similar example in a book I’m currently writing (https://www…

paragraphs.text: Interestingly, I used a very similar example in a book I’m currently writing (https://www.alexhudson.com/2017/04/08/so-what-is-strategy-anyway/) — I think it’s an excellent way to think about what strategy is and how it is useful!
paragraphs.name: f120

dccabf5a00de.title: Great points and love the strategy conversation. It isn’t done enough!

paragraphs.text: Great points and love the strategy conversation. It isn’t done enough!

One large issue I see getting in the way of great mission/vision/strategy is that it becomes too precious to get ‘approved’ by everyone that thinks they should have a say. When it gets written down it needs to be reworded and reworded.
paragraphs.name: 5b06

paragraphs.text: Thanks for the note Chris! While the toy example with the road trip sufficiently simplifies the concepts above, it definitely grossly underplays the level of challenge that a worthwhile mission should embody. Perhaps some find a cross-country road trip challenging, but most likely don’t :).

63a124f6b71c.title: The toy example you give about driving cross country is missing a key aspect: why do they want (or…

paragraphs.text: The toy example you give about driving cross country is missing a key aspect: why do they want (or need) to drive cross country? Driving cross country feels like a solution rather than a challenge.

84b53228531d.title: I love the idea of a proto-strategy!

paragraphs.text: I love the idea of a proto-strategy! I haven’t necessarily tried a “smaller process” in the past, but I think it makes perfect sense and I can very much empathize with the circumstance.
I think the main underlying point that a “proto-strategy” really gets across is this: whatever strategy you have is a hypothesis. As soon as…

675a2522c911.title: This is an excellent, no-nonsense piece that clearly distinguishes between two concepts that people…

paragraphs.text: This is an excellent, no-nonsense piece that clearly distinguishes between two concepts that people often confuse or conflate: a vision or mission is not a strategy. Awesome post. I keep referring back to it as I write my strategy doc!
paragraphs.name: 1aca

27565e1ccfa8.title: I really appreciate the post but I see mission and vision in a different way.

paragraphs.text: I really appreciate the post but I see mission and vision in a different way.
paragraphs.name: ad7f

paragraphs.text: From my point of view, vision is a broader concept, it is how the company see the evolution of their market in the future, while mission is the role they want to play in that context.
